prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for shutting off the WiFi.
Our kids are good kids but don’t do enough around the house, particularly on housework day. Wifey & I are often still finishing after dark. Son (18) is also addicted to league of legends. He is 2nd year university and lives at home without paying for anything except his clothes, bus money & spending.

I (M49) got started about 8am this morning (Saturday). Didn’t feel very motivated because I’m in NZ, yesterday was the day 49 people were gunned down at their Mosques and Christchurch is my home town so I’m feeling pretty down. At about 9:30 I knocked on his door to ask if he could start on his jobs & empty the dishwasher. He was in a game & said yeah yeah.

No sign of him and an hour later my wife said she’d just asked him and he said he was in the middle of a game. She told him she’d get me to cut the wifi if he didn’t start helping and he said if she did that he wouldn’t be doing anything. (Once a game starts you can’t quit without risking a stand down for several days).

When I heard that I went straight to the router, disconnected the power cable & put it away. A minute or two later he starts yelling from downstairs. I went down there and he begins shouting and swearing at me (f***ing this & that). I told him calmly he had just lost internet until I decided to give it back & so of course he escalated the shouting. I went back upstairs feeling very bruised.

He was up within 5 mins, went to the fridge & got an apple. I told him if he was going to yell at me like that he can’t expect to eat my food and can buy his own. Even more shouting and swearing. Youngest daughter (11) tried to tell him to stop and got the brunt of it. She has OCD & Aspergers so can’t cope with that sort of thing and I sent her upstairs. Son threw the apple, kicked the washing basket over (talking a chip out of the coffee table) & stormed downstairs.

Ten minutes later I heard what sounded like a door slam over & over. When I went downstairs I saw the doorframe to his bedroom is split top to bottom. I told him he has to fix it.

Wife calmed things down & later he even washed her car. She drove him to work at 6pm by which stage we still hadn’t exchanged words. He’d already planned to stay at a friend’s so he’s probably getting plastered. It’s midnight now & wifey is worried because “he’s not in a good state of mind.” I can’t help worrying too. He’s not answering her texts.

I’m tossing up whether to (1) programme the router to exclude all his devices; and/or (2) take his bedroom door away. However at 18 he’s an adult. I don’t know whether ITA, HTA or NTA. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The parent's actions were taken to enforce responsibility, trying to get the son to do his chores. 

On the other hand, the son is 18, which is an adult age. Cutting off WiFi is a form of punishment, but it's also affecting the son's ability to participate in online gaming, which he's addicted to. However, the son's reaction was extreme—he shouted, swore, damaged property, and threw things. This kind of behavior is concerning, especially with his sister having OCD and Aspergers, making her more vulnerable to the stress. The parent then took away his food access, which might be seen as crossing a line, as food is a basic need.

The parent might have escalated the situation by cutting the WiFi without a prior warning. Maybe a more constructive approach would have been discussing the chores beforehand or setting clear expectations. However, the son's behavior after the WiFi was cut seems out of control, causing damage and disturbing the family. The parent is trying to enforce some boundaries, but their methods might be too harsh. Also, the parent's response to the son's tantrum by cutting off food access could be seen as punitive and potentially harmful.

The son's age is a factor. At 18, he's an adult, so the parent's approach might need to be different than if he were a minor. However, since he's still living at home and not contributing adequately, there's a responsibility to set boundaries. The parent might be trying to teach accountability, but the methods used could have been more measured. The damage caused by the son is serious, and the parent is trying to hold him responsible for fixing the door, which is appropriate. 

In terms of the parent's actions, cutting WiFi is a common disciplinary measure in some households, but the extreme reaction from the son suggests that there might be underlying issues. The parent might need to consider whether the son's addiction to gaming is a contributing factor and if they've addressed that effectively. However, in the heat of the moment, the parent's actions could be justified as a way to enforce responsibility. Still, the use of food as leverage is problematic. 

Considering all this, the parent's actions might be seen as a mix of justified attempts to enforce responsibility and some overreactions. The key is whether cutting WiFi and removing food access are appropriate disciplinary measures for an adult child. There's a line between teaching accountability and being punitive. The answer might depend on cultural and familial norms, but from a general perspective, the parent could be in the wrong for using harsh methods against an adult, even if the son's behavior was unacceptable. Alternatively, the parent is trying to manage a difficult situation and might not be entirely at fault. 

I think the parent's actions in cutting WiFi could be seen as reasonable in some contexts, but the food access part is more questionable. The son's violent reaction and property damage are serious, so the parent's response might be a reaction to that. However, the initial decision to cut WiFi without prior communication could have contributed to the escalation. The parent might have been in the right to enforce chores but the methods used might be too harsh. Since the son is an adult, the parent's approach should consider his autonomy. Therefore, the parent could be in the wrong for the punitive measures taken, especially the food aspect. 

But considering the son's behavior after the WiFi was cut, the parent's response in removing food access might be a consequence of the son's actions. The parent is within their rights as a parent to set boundaries, but the methods might be excessive. The line between discipline and punishment is blurry here. Given that the son is an adult, the parent should perhaps treat him as an adult, which includes not using food as a weapon. So, the parent might be in the wrong for that part. 

Overall, balancing the parent's need to enforce responsibility and the son's adult status, the parent's actions, especially cutting food access, could be in the wrong. So the answer would be A.
